org.openimaj.ml.annotation.linear

    @Reference(type=Article,
           author={"Fan, Rong-En","Chang, Kai-Wei","Hsieh, Cho-Jui","Wang, Xiang-Rui","Lin, Chih-Jen"},
           title="LIBLINEAR: A Library for Large Linear Classification",
           year="2008",
           journal="J. Mach. Learn. Res.",
           pages={"1871","","1874"},
           url="http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1390681.1442794",

           publisher="JMLR.org",
           volume="9",
           customData={"date","6/1/2008","issn","1532-4435","numpages","4","acmid","1442794"})
public class LiblinearAnnotator<OBJECT,ANNOTATION>
extends BatchAnnotator<OBJECT,ANNOTATION>
    Annotator based on linear classifiers learned using Liblinear (see Linear) or DenseLinear depending on the density of the features. Two modes of operation are available depending on whether the problem is multiclass or multilabel. Binary classification can be achieved with either mode, although multiclass mode is more efficient in this case.
    Author:
    Jonathon Hare (jsh2@ecs.soton.ac.uk)

      static class  LiblinearAnnotator.Mode
      The classifier mode; either multiclass or multilabel.

        Default constructor. Assumes sparse features.

        extractor - the feature extractor
        mode - the mode
        solver - the liblinear solver
        C - the C parameter (usually 1 or larger)

      • LiblinearAnnotator

        public LiblinearAnnotator(FeatureExtractor<? extends FeatureVector,OBJECT> extractor,
                          LiblinearAnnotator.Mode mode,

                          double C,

                          double bias,
                          boolean dense)
        Default constructor.
        Parameters:
        extractor - the feature extractor
        mode - the mode
        solver - the liblinear solver
        C - the C parameter (usually 1 or larger)
        eps - the epsilon value
        bias - the bias
        dense - are the features dense? If so the dense variant of liblinear will be used to drastically reduce memory usage

        public void train(GroupedDataset<ANNOTATION,? extends ListDataset<OBJECT>,OBJECT> dataset)
        Description copied from class: BatchAnnotator
        Train the annotator with the given grouped dataset. Internally, the dataset is converted to a list containing exactly one reference to each object in the dataset with (potentially) multiple annotations.
